you know AI generally refers to any sort of technique that essentially enables
computers to mimic human human audience and then used logic to actually
make decisions and then essentially a subset of that kind of very broad definition of a I would be the
definition of machine learning which is essentially the subset of artificial intelligence that essentially in
includes statistical techniques that enable machines to improve at tasks with
experience by essentially learning on a data set and then one subcategory of machine learning would be deep learning
which has really kind of taken off the last 18 to 24 months with some advances in neural nets and so essentially we can
define deep learning is really the sub segment of the machine learning family that's really composed of algorithms
that essentially permit the software to train itself to perform tasks you know
very common ones in the deep learning space our speech and image recognition and this is done by essentially exposing
there was those multi layered neural networks to vast amounts of data to
essentially train the model and then have it learn how to execute on those types of tasks so we can kind of think
of AI is the broadest bucket here with machine learning essentially nested inside of that and then deep learning is
an even more targeted sub segment within within ml bromley so as we think about
you know why are so many enterprise customers making the transition to
machine learning and why are they looking to leverage these technologies you know there's really three kind of
broad benefits that enterprises are leveraging so the first is essentially in terms of automation of internal and
external processes so this is basically you know using using these large data
sets and then these models trained against the data to make identifications
of how we can optimize the existing processes to make them more efficient make them more streamlined or just make
them generally better for our customers and then also the ability to to maintain
or improve our quality and cost reduction on many of these processes as well so reducing cost is also a massive
push by enterprises in the machine learning space that second broad theme of how enterprises are benefiting from
machine learning would be essentially enrichment so this is you know more or less about adding
new features to their current products and services and then you know very specifically the ability to do things

about trends and customer preferences and and how they can best be served by by the enterprise customers and then
finally the third third part is about invention and innovation and so this is essentially the ability to take machine

a AI expertise that's already out there we're going to talk a little bit here about some of the experiences here at
amazon.com and you'll see that invention is a key theme in essentially how and
why we've adopted machine learning technologies as well so we'll kind of circle back to that then we can
essentially look at some of the different vertical industries that are out there and and you'll find that

are essentially trying to become much more self-service by using trained data
sets to better serve and then optimize the the processes that they provide actually to their citizens a really good
example of a customer to kind of help inform you know what's possible you know
with these machine learning and enlarged APIs that's is it's actually the example of FINRA and so this essentially comes
to us from the financial services segment so for those of you that aren't familiar with FINRA
I personally didn't know them before Adobe I started working with them back and around 20 2012
but essentially FINRA is the surveillance and regulatory body that
monitors every equity is an options trade in the United States that happens
on US soil so essentially they monitor all of the trades that happen on the new york stock exchange that happen on the
NASDAQ exchange sure Chicago Mercantile Exchange Chicago Board of Options in
exchange any of those exchanges that are essentially based in the US essentially
provide all of their trading data to FINRA and then on the flip side all of
the institutional traders so you know things like firms like investment banks
hedge funds etc actually have to opt in to be monitored by FINRA but essentially everybody does so
because essentially if you're not opted into FINRA then it's almost an admission
of guilt and and so the point is that they have essentially all of the transactions from both side of the house
and then they essentially run algorithms both in real time as the data comes in and then also in batch workloads at the
end of the day that essentially monitor for fraudulent transactions and so this
is a massive data set they're tracking on the order of seven seven billion daily market events and have over 30
petabytes of data essentially in this environment and they essentially use their machine learning workloads to detect that
suspicious activity across transactions and then be able to take action on it so it's a great example of a massive scale
customer that's that's running these types of machine learning workloads on AWS today so flipping to the the history

accurate in terms of the recommendations that we give to customers of various products on our retail website there's a
huge benefit to our customers and then likewise if we can increase efficiency even by you know a fraction of a percent
in our supply chain there's huge benefit that that we're able to reap that we can
in turn essentially pass back to our customers through cost savings so automating processes has been a massive

actually drive voice driven interactions we're creating entirely new customer experiences by using machine learning
and deep learning behind the scenes and so you'll find that many of the customer experiences that people have come to
expect from Amazon are actually driven by machine learning and deep learning behind the scenes this slide is
important because we want to just call out that you know as we start to think about you know building our capabilities
for machine learning in AI we actually want to think very holistically about these challenges and then the platform that we're choosing to

we need to think about and rather than becoming you know too fixated on you know building machine learning and AI
capabilities just because it's kind of the flavor of the day and it's a you know for good reason
you know there's new use cases that are you know achievable and solvable now with machine learning that weren't say
18 months ago but at the same time we want to think more holistically about what we're actually trying to accomplish
which is that we're essentially trying to create an entire data platform for our organization that essentially gives
us the collection of capabilities that allow us to answer any type of question that's going to come along that's
answerable with data and so for that reason we want to think holistically about that overall data platform of which AI and machine learning
capabilities are just one very important set of capabilities and so we want to think all the way from products that
help us to ingest the data and get the data into our data environment and then in that second tier of orange boxes we
want to start to think about the storage tiers so everything from raw object-based storage we can create a
data Lake and essential repository for the data at massive scale and very low cost and then up into even more
specialized storage tiers such as relational or non-relational databases and then finally is that piece to
essentially apply the analytics capability so now that we've you know ingested and stored the data now we want
to actually you know apply analytics and derive intelligence and smarts from it and so this spans everything from
traditional batch analytics solutions like data warehouses and Amazon redshift or Hadoop clusters and Amazon EMR to now
the essentially next-generation machine learning and deep learning capabilities that we can apply for the data as well so the key point here is that you just
want to think holistically about are you building that data platform that gives you all of these capabilities so that as
you build and staff data science teams they constantly have the right tool for the job so now as we think about the
machine learning and AI capability very specifically as it relates to AWS this is essentially a summary of the machine
learning platform that AWS is building within our cloud and essentially the ways that that we're investing in this platform
and capability for our customers so really namely there's there's four foot four two to three tiers of of
investment in platform that we're making so basically you start at the very base with important cloud infrastructure
investments that we're making to essentially provide the best most optimized environment for running
machine learning and deep learning in the cloud that spans up into the various frameworks that developers want to work
with you know data scientists and machine learning practitioners I want to work with these various frameworks to
create their models and to train on data and then into the third tier which is platform services so that essentially
developers and customers have access to managed environments to do these things and then finally the very top layer
which is what we call our application AI services and so these are essentially pre-trained models where we make
functionalities such as say facial facial analysis and facial recognition in our recognition product available to
customers by a simple API call from a model that's basically been pre trained in a non customizable from from AWS so
that the customer has very easy access to to build in that type of capability into their application so as we take a
little bit of a deeper look at kind of each of these four tiers so you know what's important in in the
infrastructure layer and the investments that we're making there so that again this is about making you know the latest
and greatest infrastructure that's also most performant for things like training machine learning and training deep
learning models available to our customers so a very good example of this is our Amazon p3 instances which were
released back in October of last year and so essentially the p3 is based on the Nvidia Volta v100 GPU architecture
which is essentially designed by Nvidia from the ground up specifically to run deep learning and to train these types
of models and for that reason it's it's extremely highly performant for various frameworks like tensor flow and MX net
that it's been optimized for and it's a vast improvement over the previous even just the previous generation of NVIDIA
GPU because again it was made purposely for these types of applications so you'll find that even the previous
generation p2 which was an instance type also based on the NVIDIA GPUs within
NATO base cloud that was only about 14 to 16 months old when the p3s came out that the p3 actually provides up to 14x
better performance and and so the the point is that you know data scientists
that are looking for the best performance for their tensorflow or for their MX net workloads I can't find any
better performance anywhere else other than then the Nvidia Volt to be 100's based on our p3 so we're very excited to
provide developers that want to run deep learning models the best performance for tensorflow and MX net and cafe 2 and all
those various frameworks via the the P 3s in ec2 in the Amazon environment that
takes us to our second tier which is very tightly coupled with those infrastructure investments that we're making so you know in addition to having
the latest and greatest GPUs and the best FPGAs for training or UC to enhance
networking to make those clusters run together for the infrastructure layer now we also want a couple essentially
the the various deep learning frameworks that deep learning developers and data scientists want to work with and want to
train with and so the approach that Amazon is taking here which is a little bit different to some of the other
providers out there is that we're actually taking a very open approach to essentially enable developers access to
all of the tools that they want to use here so we're not basically saying that there's one tool that's the the right
fit for all of the different jobs and that developers should predict a towards that single tool instead what we're
saying is that will essentially enable all of these frameworks so you've probably heard of things like tensor flow and like MX net and chain ER and PI
torch etc these are the the programming frameworks that the customers want to
work with and so our approach is to essentially optimize our infrastructure so things like the p3 instance types are
optimized for the most popular frameworks so for example Tuncer flow and MX net are two of those most popular
ones that that our infrastructure and our platform services are optimized to run with but at the same time will
continue to support other frameworks that may be you know slightly more niche like something like cafe 2 or CNC K because again we want customers to have
access to all of those frameworks the way we you know there's kind of two main reasons why we do that one is that it's
very early days in this in this market and and then kind of in this technology space so it's hard to understand how this space will
shake out and you see new frameworks coming along all the time so hi torch is a great example where eighteen months
back it didn't really exist in this marketplace and now it's arguably running you know third in the market and
has been very popular with developers so there will be new technology developments and new frameworks coming
out constantly and we want to make sure that our our customers have access to those and then secondly we think that
you know as the space develops and there's many good tools in this marketplace particularly large enterprises are going to want to have
access to various different tools in their toolbox so that as they tackle different types of applications they'll
have access to those so for example as I mentioned earlier Cafe Tuesday little bit more of a kind of somewhat niche
framework here it's not maybe as mainstream as things like tensorflow and apache MX net but as it turns out cafe 2
is actually really good for facial recognition so it may turn out that you know at a large enterprise customer you know most of the the mainstream deep
learning and machine learning algorithms are written in tensorflow but then the teams that work on computer vision want
access to the cafe tool and so we'll make make it essentially access to all of these tools to mix and match
accessible to our customers so that they can have the flexibility to have the right tool for the job and then to have
their environment essentially transformed with the the market technologies in use cases over time this
takes us into our third tier the platform which we call the machine learning managed services so namely the
the main product here that's very important that we just announced it our reinvent conference back in November is
the Amazon Sage Maker product so essentially this is a hosted managed environment for building training and
then deploying deep learning models and so essentially you can run all of those very popular deep learning frameworks
such as tensorflow and MX net in cafe and other algorithms in Sage Maker and
so essentially what you have is is really three different environments that can either fit together or be used
independently so basically the first piece is that build component of the model so essentially what it is is a
hosted Jupiter note booking environment which is essentially the environment you know open-source based environment that
data scientists want to work in to basically explore and manage their data is the first piece then the second piece
is the actual or sorry hosting of the training so you're able to actually have one-click
deployment to go from your build environment in the Jupiter notebook essentially into managed training and
and the environment also gives you the ability to tune the hyper parameters and essentially drive the best performance
possible and the system actually uses machine learning to enhance your machine learning algorithms and it actually
makes recommendations of how to tweak those hyper parameters to basically make the models run more efficiently inside
of Sage maker and so what you find is that the training component is actually also very open as well so it's basically
based on docker container is a ssin so any sort of algorithm that can run on a docker container can actually run in
Sage maker so while we inherently have provided support for and optimized for tensorflow and MX net anything that can
fit into a docker container can actually run in Sage makers you can actually bring a custom algorithm written in a
custom language that was you know 10 or 15 years old and if that can fit on a docker container image it can run in
Sage maker so it's providing huge flexibility for our customers to essentially run their frameworks and
then finally the last piece is deployment and so this is basically once we have the model trained up and we're now actually making predictions and
inference out of it we now have the ability to basically host you know host that deployment host
that inference and basically have an API endpoint that our applications can now call against and essentially have
one-click deployment out of that train environment so customers are using sage maker for building training and then
deploying their deep learning models in AWS this brings us to our fourth and
final tier which is the application AI or machine learning services and so
essentially we have really three kind of broad Kotik categories of functionality today so basically vision conversational
chat BOTS and then language and so again these are essentially pre-trained models that amazon has created and actually
trained against data to do very specific applications so if you take a look at our recognition image our recognition
video service this essentially allows us to detect things within either still
images or within video and so namely you can detect objects and scenes you can
also detect faces and characteristics with those faces then you can also detect text with
conversational chat BOTS we have Amazon Lex which essentially takes the natural language understanding
and deep learning engine of Amazon Alexa and now makes it embeddable into other
applications to essentially create chat BOTS then we have Amazon Poli which
essentially is the spoken voice of Alexa which essentially allows us to translate written text and give it a voice we have
Amazon Translate which is essentially machine translations that if we have you know particularly a common use case here
at Amazon is that we have customer reviews where a customer may purchase a product on our German website and
they'll review the product there and then if we actually sell that product in the United States that review could
potentially be very useful to someone here if they could only understand it and see it you know if they don't speak
German then it's not as useful and so we can actually now use machine translation to translate that review and in German
into English and now the person here can consume it so that's Amazon translate then we have Amazon transcribe which is
essentially the reverse of Pali which allows you to take spoken spoken words and then turn it into a transcription
and a textual format and then finally have Amazon comprehend which is essentially NLP or natural language
processing to essentially pull out entities and key words from text and also pull out sentiment so a good
example of customers using the application AI services I think one last point to to make before I kind of move
on to the decease be in use case is that if you think about the types of users internally at our customers that are
using the various tiers of our stack you'll find that there's actually a differentiation between between the type
of users that's going to use the bottom three pieces versus the very top so to be very clear that the bottom three
pieces from infrastructure up through the frameworks and then even into the manage platform services such as Amazon
Sage maker are very much targeted at the data science teams and the machine learning practitioners and you know
people that are highly skilled working with data that maybe have a PhD in math and our you know trained and things like tons are flown IMAX net these are the
data practitioners that want to get hands on with the model and basically do something very granular and work with the data where's the top tier the
application AI services are actually not talking as much at that that power type of user
and data scientists but it's actually targeted more it kind of general developers who who aren't familiar with
you know how to create and train their own model they don't know tensorflow they don't know a max net they just want
to build in a common application such as facial analysis and basically get on with their job and so if they can
consume that pre trained model by a simple API calls from AWS then they're able to build in that functionality and
then get on with their job and so that's kind of the delineation in terms of the user base across these so coming back to
the c-span case essentially what c-span did is they're able to actually use Amazon recognition to tag the footage
across their their network so obviously c-span broadcasts what's happening in
the United States government so there's you know broadcast from all of the hearings in Congress typically people
aren't going to want to sit through and watch hours and hours and hours of that footage but what they're very interested in our specific occurrences specific
events and then more importantly specific individuals so you may want to look up you know what is the senator
from your state been up to the last two weeks and you can actually go to their website and basically type in an individual politician and then basically
pull all of the footage and occurrences of them over that time period and so previously they actually had humans
tagged all of this footage where they would basically watch all of the footage stop at every 30 seconds take a look at
the politicians that were in the frame and then tagged those names to it and so this is as you can imagine that's a
pretty immense effort and they were you know wasting about 9,000 hours a year and labor just doing that and so what
they're able to do now is they're actually able to automate that footage tagging with Amazon recognition and so
essentially they're able to again take those stills every 30 seconds of the footage they have their own database
that they've created with 99 thousand known politicians and then essentially recognition is able to match the faces
in the frame work against that database and when there's matches essentially tag it in automate this whole process which
again because they're just using simple API calls into that pre-configured a Amazon model that's been trained in
recognition they were able to build this application in only three weeks
